instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> - 27/28 is 20.6 ohm.  17/18 resistance is 47 ohm.

where should I look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
"17/18 resistance is 47 ohm."
Fix that first; check <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 and traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> is replaced. now 17/18 resistance 3.5 ohm.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still 4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
Check the R/C networks from pins 5, 7, 8.
Check/replace <CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR>.
Resolder entire <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> area (surrounding components too).

Fan dont spin.

threads.message: Post voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
SCL/SDA lines are easy available at battery connector.

Try, always when possible, to measure touching surrounding components of QFN chips.
Not a good idea to touch directly chip pins; is very easy to make short...

Yes, replace possible.
Before applying power, check no short present on board.
Pay atention to <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/35.

threads.message:

Also, how come yesterday I was getting  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 12.2v below i blow the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and now after replacement it is 8.1v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
Maybe bad ISL, or solders.
Check diode mode on SCL/SDA lines, w/ and w/o <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> soldered.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>/81 are both good.

threads.message: ah.. <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> is shorted to ground.

i checked pin 2 of <DIODE>D6950</DIODE> is shorted to ground...i removed it to test, doesnt help.

I also removed <CAPACITOR>C6953</CAPACITOR> to check, doesnt help. 

Bad SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
Remove <DIODE>D6950</DIODE> first.
If still short, remove <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
yes, actually not exactly pin 10 and pin 11 as the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> has been removed as per your instruction.

I measured these value at  <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>  and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> and diode mode show these value.. are they not normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
Less than 1% difference allowed.
Remove other components connected on that bus and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
the diode mode value of pin 10 seems to be correct as I cross checked with a good board.

the other components on the pin 11 bus seems to be only: J6950 , J6955, <CAPACITOR>C6953</CAPACITOR> (removed), <DIODE>D6950</DIODE> (removed), <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR>(resistance value is good and same as <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>) and the SMC

Did I miss anything?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
Pin 11 has too high reading; supposing you measured with red probe at ground.
So is not the case to remove something from that line.
Your problem is a broken trace, or bad solder at SMC probably, or <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
Yes but you told me to remove the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> already... so with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> out, those are the reading from pin 10 and pin 11 and you said less than 1% difference allowed. 

When you said "Remove other components connected on that bus", were you refering to components that are attached to pin 10 or pin 11?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message:
You have a higher value than expected on the SCL line.
In such case should be broken line, or bad solder.
But high value can be normal if both SMC and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> are removed.
If at least one is on the board, the value should be around 550-700, like you have on SDA.

If none (SMC, or <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>) are soldered, then maybe SDA line has problems, because should be higher in such case.
Then you can suspect a component with leakage.

How ever, you should check disconnecting J6955 and may need to remove <CAPACITOR>C6952</CAPACITOR>/53 (if present).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message: i have removed both SMC and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, now both pin 10 and pin 11 are high value around 1087

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot no fan spin <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4v
threads.message: Now start resoldering the components one by one, and check the values each time.
